docs.text: denzel washington is among the many actors this holiday season to give very impressive milestone performances .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this perhaps may be washington's very best to date .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he joins matt damon and jim carrey in having the talent , this season , to become his character , copying mannerisms and personal styles perfectly .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his very believable performance makes the long and uninteresting " the hurricane " a much better film than it actually is .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when his rubin " hurricane " carter feels pain and is tormented by racism , he creates for the audience a great sense of sympathy , disgust , and maybe even some embarrassment from the fact that this is our very own country that is breaking laws to support silly prejudices .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the horrific true events carter suffered from all of his life are slightly more disturbing and terrifying because they only took place a few decades ago .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the powerful expressions of denzel washington alone , as his tortured carter , sum up the troubles of racism in america's history .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he is that amazing .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the problem with " the hurricane " is that when compared to washington , all of the other actors are not nearly as memorable in their roles .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: mainly because the script focuses so much on carter , that it leaves little interest or room for the other actors .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is , without a doubt , washington's movie but in order for any film to be completely satisfying , it must utilize everyone in the cast to their highest potential not just the stars .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: denzel washington is the only reason to see this film for his inspirational and very depressing tour de force performance .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: as rubin carter , we see a black man whose existence has been a punching bag for the white american court system .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: >from the age of eleven to twenty one he was sent to a juvenile prison for a crime he did not commit .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: then after a successful marriage and boxing career , he was harshly imprisoned again for life after being framed for a triple murder .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: carter's second term in prison seemed almost inevitable when faced off against jealous , powerful white men who refused to let him succeed .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: from these past experiences in jail , carter realized that he must make his case heard for all of america .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: after several court appeals , an autobiography , and many public marches for his freedom , carter remained locked in prison .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it was not until a young black boy from brooklyn being educated in toronto read carter's book in the 1980's , that a serious battle for freedom took place .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the young boy and his three canadian guardians decide to dedicate all of their time to the case until carter is released .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the greatest scenes in the film are when carter begins to lose his mind after spending three months in isolation .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: washington really shows the breakdown of carter when after swearing he would never go to jail again , he is unfairly framed at the height of his innocent career .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the devastation in washington's eyes show a man who has struggled to do the right thing his whole life only to be punished for it .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in the hole , carter attempts to maintain emotional balance but he cannot .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his anger is heightened to a point of no control .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: we see multiple carters , a violent angry one , a silent passive one , and a mediator .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: we see an emotional boxing match inside carter's head .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: from this point in the hole to the end of the film , this fight continues .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is very apparent at times which side is winning the battle and in some scenes there is a direct switch from angry to caring or the opposite .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when carter sees that white canadians want to help him get out of prison , the angry carter at first erupts .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: white people have been trying to hurt him his whole life , this reminder leads to anger in his head .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: however , as the film continues and the canadians continue to help carter we see the calm side him .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he realizes that society is changing .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: that racism is decreasing and now carter wants to leave jail immediately and become a part of this world .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: very rarely have i seen such determination to perfect his role as washington has done here .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if only the other actors had this same determination .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: dan hedaya , ridiculously plays the man who sends carter to prison twice by forcing witnesses to lie and switching evidence around .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it felt like his character was taken straight out of a " scooby doo " episode ; he would have gotten away with it if it wasn't for those annoying little kids .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " the kids " in this film are the three canadians who are terribly underused making their relationship with carter underdeveloped and unbelievable .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the lawyers who help release carter also are underused , as is clancy brown as a kind prison guard ( the complete opposite of his character in " shawshank redemption " ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: there is a great amount of talent in this supporting cast but it just never appears .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: hedaya was superb in " clueless , " same for david paymer in " get shorty , " harris yulin in " ghostbusters " and liev schreiber in " the daytrippers . "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is a mystery how this many actors signed on to such shallow roles .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: on the other hand , it is absolutely no mystery why denzel washington agreed to play rubin " hurricane " carter .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this role is about as far off from shallow as you can get .
docs.label: positive
